moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3
comment:
At that time 4.Qd3 was thought to be some sort of
confutation for this kind of opening. Nowadays it is rarely played in
tournament practice because the theory has shown that Black can come out with
a good position with no difficulty.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5
comment: The best. The developement 5.Nf3 is less promising.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6
comment:
Not to be prefer
red is 5... Na6 6. a3 (6. Bg5 Qa5 7. Bxf6 gxf6 8. e3 Nxc5 9. Qc2 Bxc3+ 10.
bxc3 b6) (6. g3 Qa5 7. Bd2 Nxc5 8. Qc2 Nce4) 6... Bxc5 (6... Bxc3+ 7. Qxc3
Nxc5 8. f3 and White has advantage.) 7. Nf3 O-O 8. Bg5 Be7 9. e4 h6 10. Bh4 b6
11. e5 Nh5 and Black's position is good in every variation.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3
comment:
Less convi
ncing are the alternatives 6. Bd2 6... Bxc5 7. e3 O-O 8. Nf3 d5 and 6.Bg5 Bxc5
7. Nf3 Be7 8. e3 O-O 9. Rd1 Qa5 10. Be2 d5 and Black's play is acceptable.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2
comment:
Very good. It was tried 7... Nxc5 8. Qc2 f5 9. a3 Bxc3
10. Bxc3 O-O 11. b4 Ne4 12.Bb2 but such a variation hardly allows Black to
keep equality.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5
comment:
According to the modern theory 8...f5 is
preferable. The move in the text is inaccurate.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3
comment:
Mikenas: "The
Yugoslavian Grandmaster Trifunovic indicated the continuation 9.Nde4 Be7 10.
0-0-0 as preferable, with initiative to White. For me it is just matter of
taste".

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5
comment: All already seen in the practice.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5
comment:
Such an opportunity can not be lost. It is necessary to remind that Black has
the Bishop pair and any small hesitation can allow him to take initiative.
With this move White wants to activate his play on the queenside.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4
comment:
A blunder! More precisely: a serious inaccuracy. 18.Nxc5 Bxc5 19.b4
had to be played, with clear advantage for White. Fortunately it is not an
irreparaple mistake.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4
comment: Here it is! Can you see the difference?

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3
comment:
Now White must play "very" accurately to avoid further pain. 19. bxa5
cxd3 20. Rxc7 dxe2 and Black's position is ok.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3
comment:
Mikenas does not want to play passively and ... takes some risks. His
opponent had 3 minutes left to the time control (at that time it was 32 moves
in two hours) and our hero, with the move in the text, tried to profit from
this fact. It is a dangerous tactics, but sometimes it pays. Mikenas says, to
be more precise: "Yes, but more often our attempts to be too smart, to confuse
things, turn against ourselves". Of course the right move (and the expected
one) was 21.Bxf3.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3 Bf6 22. Qc2 Rb8 23. Nd3
comment:
A bit of tactics to force
Black to use his time and think of a new plan. It was right to play 23. Nxc4
Rxb4 24. Nxa5 Qxa5 25. Rxd7 with possibilities for both players.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3 Bf6 22. Qc2 Rb8 23. Nd3 d5
comment:
Mikenas: "Black is pursuing his excellent play and is not caring about zeitnot.
Indeed I overlooked this move. Now, in caso of 24.bxa5 Qxa5 the White Knight
could not leave the square d3 because of 25.Rb2. I could not rely on a logical
play: I had to find another trick and pray the "God of the North" for a happy
ending.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3 Bf6 22. Qc2 Rb8 23. Nd3 d5 24. Nf4 Rfe8
comment:
And Black falls into the trap! The right reply was 24...
Qc6 and White would have had nearly nothing left.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3 Bf6 22. Qc2 Rb8 23. Nd3 d5 24. Nf4 Rfe8 25. bxa5 g5
comment:
There are no
other possibiliteis. In case of 25...Rb2 the reply would have been 26.Qa4!
attacking the Rook in e8 (that is why it was necessary to play 24. ..Qc6
instead of 24...Re8).

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3 Bf6 22. Qc2 Rb8 23. Nd3 d5 24. Nf4 Rfe8 25. bxa5 g5 26. Nh5 Be5 27. f4 gxf4 28. exf4 Bxf4 29. Nf6+
comment:
It is true that White is a piece up but, please, look at the Pawn army which
available for Black. White must be very careful, or the little black men will
become very dangerous.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3 Bf6 22. Qc2 Rb8 23. Nd3 d5 24. Nf4 Rfe8 25. bxa5 g5 26. Nh5 Be5 27. f4 gxf4 28. exf4 Bxf4 29. Nf6+ Kh8 30. Nxe8 Rxe8 31. Qc3+ e5 32. Rb1 Qg7+ 33. Kf1
comment:
The only one After 33. Kh1 Qh6 34. h3 d4 White would be forced to give
back a Rook.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3 Bf6 22. Qc2 Rb8 23. Nd3 d5 24. Nf4 Rfe8 25. bxa5 g5 26. Nh5 Be5 27. f4 gxf4 28. exf4 Bxf4 29. Nf6+ Kh8 30. Nxe8 Rxe8 31. Qc3+ e5 32. Rb1 Qg7+ 33. Kf1 Bxh2 34. Ke1 d4 35. Qxc4
comment: No hurry! White has just to keep calm.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. Qb3 c5 5. dxc5 Nc6 6. Nf3 Ne4 7. Bd2 Nxd2 8. Nxd2 Bxc5 9. e3 O-O 10. Nf3 b6 11. Be2 Bb7 12. O-O f5 13. Na4 Be7 14. Rfd1 Qc7 15. Rac1 Na5 16. Qd3 Rad8 17. c5 bxc5 18. b4 c4 19. Qc3 Bc6 20. Nb2 Bxf3 21. gxf3 Bf6 22. Qc2 Rb8 23. Nd3 d5 24. Nf4 Rfe8 25. bxa5 g5 26. Nh5 Be5 27. f4 gxf4 28. exf4 Bxf4 29. Nf6+ Kh8 30. Nxe8 Rxe8 31. Qc3+ e5 32. Rb1 Qg7+ 33. Kf1 Bxh2 34. Ke1 d4 35. Qxc4 e4 36. Rxd4
comment:
Taking the Queen
would have been dangerous: 36.Qxd4 Be5! followed by 37...Bc3+ and 38... Rg8.
